\chapter{Home}
\label{\detokenize{home:home}}\label{\detokenize{home::doc}}
\noindent\sphinxincludegraphics[scale=0.2]{{0b7d3a5122e15f3f28772b2764e411992b2b3300}.png}

\sphinxAtStartPar
LoanPy is a linguistic toolkit to detect ancient borrowings computationally.
It was part of my dissertation\sphinxhyphen{}project at the \sphinxhref{https://finno-ugristik.univie.ac.at/en/}{Finno\sphinxhyphen{}Ugric department
of the University of Vienna},
which aimed to answer the question whether there are any Gothic loanwords
in Hungarian. The project was partly funded by the
\sphinxhref{https://www.helsinki.fi/en}{University of Helsinki}
and the \sphinxhref{https://www.eva.mpg.de/index/}{Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology} in Leipzig.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The software offers following features:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Extraction of sound and phonotactic correspondences from etymological data

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Predictions on loanword adaptation and historical reconstruction

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Evaluation of the quality of the predictive models

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Searching for phonetic and semantic matches between two lists of
form\sphinxhyphen{}meaning pairs

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
LoanPy adheres to the standards set forth by the \sphinxhref{https://cldf.clld.org}{Cross\sphinxhyphen{}Linguistic
Data Formats (CLDF)} initiative.

\chapter{Tutorial}
\label{\detokenize{tutorial:tutorial}}\label{\detokenize{tutorial::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This tutorial will walk you through the process of using loanpy to
discover old loanwords.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Here is an illustration of the loanword detection framework with a minimal
example:

\begin{figure}[htbp]
\centering
\capstart

\noindent\sphinxincludegraphics{{workflow}.png}
\caption{Mine sound
correspondences from an etymological dictionary, evaluate their predictive
power, input them to a sound change applier to generate pseudo\sphinxhyphen{}adapted and
pseudo\sphinxhyphen{}proto\sphinxhyphen{}forms, and search for phonetic and semantic matches between
those predictions.}\label{\detokenize{tutorial:id1}}\end{figure}


\section{Step 1: Mine sound correspondences}
\label{\detokenize{tutorial:step-1-mine-sound-correspondences}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Grab an etymological dictionary and mine information of how sounds
and phonotactic patterns changed during horizontal and vertical transfers.

\sphinxAtStartPar
In the minimal example, our dictionary contains only one etymology, namely
a horizontal transfer “gigi ← gege” and a vertical one “kiki \textless{} gigi”.
If we mine the sound correspondences we get the rule “g from g, i from e”
in horizontal transfers and “k from g, i from i” in vertical ones.
In terms of phonotactics, we can mine “CVCV from CVCV” both horizontally
and vertically.

\sphinxAtStartPar
This is achieved with \sphinxhref{https://loanpy.readthedocs.io/en/latest/documentation.html\#loanpy.scminer.get\_correspondences}{loanpy.scminer.get\_correspondences}

\sphinxAtStartPar
For an implementation with a detailed guide visit \sphinxhref{https://ronataswestoldturkic.readthedocs.io/en/latest/mkloanpy.html}{Part 3 (steps 1\sphinxhyphen{}4) of
ronataswestoldturkic’s documentation}.


\section{Step 2: Evaluate the predictive model}
\label{\detokenize{tutorial:step-2-evaluate-the-predictive-model}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
How good are the predictions made from the mined sound correspondences?

\sphinxAtStartPar
Our minimal example is a perfect model that predicts with 100\% certainty that
\textless{}kiki\textgreater{} goes back to \textless{}gigi\textgreater{} and that the donor form of \textless{}gigi\textgreater{} is \textless{}gege\textgreater{}.

\sphinxAtStartPar
This is achieved with \sphinxhref{https://loanpy.readthedocs.io/en/latest/documentation.html\#loanpy.eval\_sca.eval\_one}{loanpy.eval\_sca.eval\_one}

\sphinxAtStartPar
For an implementation with a detailed guide
employing concepts from statistics such as \sphinxhref{https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cross-validation\_(statistics)\#Leave-one-out\_cross-validation}{leave\sphinxhyphen{}one out cross\sphinxhyphen{}validation
(LOOCV)},
the \sphinxhref{https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Receiver\_operating\_characteristic}{receiver operating characteristics (ROC) \sphinxhyphen{}curve},
and the \sphinxhref{https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Receiver\_operating\_characteristic\#Area\_under\_the\_curve}{area under the curve (AUC)},
visit \sphinxhref{https://ronataswestoldturkic.readthedocs.io/en/latest/mkloanpy.html}{steps 5\sphinxhyphen{}6 in part 3 of ronataswestoldturkic’s
documentation}


\section{Step 3: Apply sound correspondences}
\label{\detokenize{tutorial:step-3-apply-sound-correspondences}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Take the information mined from the etymological dictionary
and apply it to unseen words.
Create hypothetical proto\sphinxhyphen{} and adapted forms by simulating their horizontal
and vertical changes.

\sphinxAtStartPar
In the minimal example this means predicting that \textless{}ikki\textgreater{} must go back to
\textless{}iggi\textgreater{} and \textless{}iikk\textgreater{} to \textless{}iigg\textgreater{}, based on the mined sound correspondences for
vertical transfers. Likewise, \textless{}egeg\textgreater{} must turn into \textless{}igig\textgreater{} and \textless{}egge\textgreater{} into
\textless{}iggi\textgreater{} during horizontal transfers, based on the extracted sound
correspondences.

\sphinxAtStartPar
This is achieved with the \sphinxhref{https://loanpy.readthedocs.io/en/latest/documentation.html\#module-loanpy.scapplier}{loanpy.scapplier}
module

\sphinxAtStartPar
For an implementation with a detailed guide to predict vertical transfers visit
\sphinxhref{https://gerstnerhungarian.readthedocs.io/en/latest/?badge=latest}{gerstnerhungarian’s documentation} and for
predicting horizontal transfers (loanwords) visit
\sphinxhref{https://koeblergothic.readthedocs.io/en/latest/?badge=latest}{koeblergothic’s documentation}.


\section{Step 4: Find old loanwords}
\label{\detokenize{tutorial:step-4-find-old-loanwords}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Search for phonetic matches between predicted loanword adaptations
and predicted proto\sphinxhyphen{}forms. Calculate the semantic similarity of
the meanings associated with each form in a match. List the phonetic matches
with the highest semantic similarity.

\sphinxAtStartPar
In our minimal example this means to first go through the \sphinxhref{https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cartesian\_product}{cartesian product} of phonetic matches.
If our criterion for a match is phonetic identity, we get:
\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
iggi \sphinxhyphen{} igig: no match

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
iigg \sphinxhyphen{} igig: no match

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
iggi \sphinxhyphen{} iggi: MATCH

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
iigg \sphinxhyphen{} iggi: no match

\end{enumerate}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Now we can register that \textless{}iggi\textgreater{} is our only match. The meanings associated
with it are “cat” and “dog”. If we assess these two meanings as sufficiently
similar, then we can propose a new etymology: \textless{}ikki\textgreater{} “cat” goes back to
a proto\sphinxhyphen{}form \textless{}iggi\textgreater{}, which was borrowed from \textless{}egge\textgreater{} “dog”.

\sphinxAtStartPar
This is achieved with the \sphinxhref{https://loanpy.readthedocs.io/en/latest/documentation.html\#module-loanpy.loanfinder}{loanpy.loanfinder}
module

\sphinxAtStartPar
For an implementation with a detailed guide visit
\sphinxhref{https://gothichungarian.readthedocs.io/en/latest/?badge=latest}{GothicHungarian’s documentation}.


\section{Conclusion}
\label{\detokenize{tutorial:conclusion}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Congratulations, you’ve completed this tutorial on loanpy! You should now
have a good understanding of how to use loanpy to find old loanwords.

\sphinxAtStartPar
If you have any questions or feedback, please don’t hesitate to reach out
to me, e.g. via \sphinxhref{mailto:viktor\_martinovic@\$removethis\$eva.mpg.de}{e\sphinxhyphen{}mail} or
\sphinxhref{https://twitter.com/martino\_vik}{Twitter}.


\section{Further Reading}
\label{\detokenize{tutorial:further-reading}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
LoanPy was part of my dissertation\sphinxhyphen{}project.
A link to the monograph will be made public as soon as available,
probably around September 2023. Stay tuned.

to run them offline on your computer and on

\section{Sound Correspondence Miner}
\label{\detokenize{documentation:module-loanpy.scminer}}\label{\detokenize{documentation:sound-correspondence-miner}}\index{module@\spxentry{module}!loanpy.scminer@\spxentry{loanpy.scminer}}\index{loanpy.scminer@\spxentry{loanpy.scminer}!module@\spxentry{module}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The sound correspondence miner module contains several functions to
extract and manipulate linguistic data stored in tab\sphinxhyphen{}separated tables.
The main function is \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{get\_correspondences}}, which extracts sound and prosodic
correspondences from the table and returns them as six dictionaries, each
with corresponding frequencies and COGID values. The module also includes
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{uralign}}, a function that aligns Uralic input strings based on custom
rules, and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{get\_heur}}, which computes a heuristic mapping between phonemes
in a target language’s phoneme inventory and all phonemes in the IPA sound
system based on the Euclidean distance of their feature vectors. Finally,
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{get\_prosodic\_inventory}} extracts all types of prosodic structures
from a target language in a given etymological table.
\index{get\_correspondences() (in module loanpy.scminer)@\spxentry{get\_correspondences()}\spxextra{in module loanpy.scminer}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{documentation:loanpy.scminer.get_correspondences}}
\pysigstartsignatures
\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{loanpy.scminer.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{get\_correspondences}}}{\sphinxparam{\DUrole{n,n}{table}\DUrole{p,p}{:}\DUrole{w,w}{  }\DUrole{n,n}{List\DUrole{p,p}{{[}}List\DUrole{p,p}{{[}}str\DUrole{p,p}{{]}}\DUrole{p,p}{{]}}}}, \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n,n}{heur}\DUrole{p,p}{:}\DUrole{w,w}{  }\DUrole{n,n}{Dict\DUrole{p,p}{{[}}str\DUrole{p,p}{,}\DUrole{w,w}{  }List\DUrole{p,p}{{[}}str\DUrole{p,p}{{]}}\DUrole{p,p}{{]}}}\DUrole{w,w}{  }\DUrole{o,o}{=}\DUrole{w,w}{  }\DUrole{default_value}{\textquotesingle{}\textquotesingle{}}}}{{ $\rightarrow$ List\DUrole{p,p}{{[}}Dict\DUrole{p,p}{{]}}}}
\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Get sound and prosodic correspondences from a given table string.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Parameters}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{table}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{list}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{ of }}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{lists}}) \textendash{} A list of lists representing an etymological table.
It must contain columns
named \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ALIGNMENT}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{PROSODY}}, and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{COGID}}.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{heur}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{dictionary with IPA characters as keys and a list}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{ of
}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{phonemes}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{ of }}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{a language\textquotesingle{}s phoneme inventory ranked
according to feature vector similarity as values.}}) \textendash{} Optional dictionary containing heuristic correspondences
to be merged with the output. Defaults to an empty string.

\end{itemize}

\sphinxlineitem{Returns}
\sphinxAtStartPar

\sphinxAtStartPar
A list of six dictionaries containing correspondences
and their frequencies:
\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{)}%
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Sound correspondences.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Frequency of sound correspondences.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
COGID values for sound correspondences.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Prosodic correspondences.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Frequency of prosodic correspondences.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
COGID values for prosodic correspondences.

\end{enumerate}


\sphinxlineitem{Return type}
\sphinxAtStartPar
list of six dictionaries

\end{description}\end{quote}

\index{get\_heur() (in module loanpy.scminer)@\spxentry{get\_heur()}\spxextra{in module loanpy.scminer}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{documentation:loanpy.scminer.get_heur}}
\pysigstartsignatures
\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{loanpy.scminer.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{get\_heur}}}{\sphinxparam{\DUrole{n,n}{tgtlg}\DUrole{p,p}{:}\DUrole{w,w}{  }\DUrole{n,n}{str}}}{{ $\rightarrow$ Dict\DUrole{p,p}{{[}}str\DUrole{p,p}{,}\DUrole{w,w}{  }List\DUrole{p,p}{{[}}str\DUrole{p,p}{{]}}\DUrole{p,p}{{]}}}}
\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Rank the phonemes of a target langauge’s phoneme inventory according
to feature vector similarity to all IPA sounds.
Relies on \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{./cldf/.transcription\sphinxhyphen{}report.json}} which contains the
phoneme inventory. The file \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ipa\_all.csv}} contains all IPA sounds
and their feature vectors and is shipped together with loanpy.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Parameters}
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{tgtlg}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}) \textendash{} The ID of the target language, as defined in
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{etc/languages.tsv}} in a CLDF repository.

\sphinxlineitem{Returns}
\sphinxAtStartPar
A dictionary with IPA phonemes as keys and a list of
closest target language phonemes as values.

\sphinxlineitem{Return type}
\sphinxAtStartPar
dict

\sphinxlineitem{Raises}
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{FileNotFoundError}} \textendash{} If the data file or the transcription
report file is not found.

\end{description}\end{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxhref{https://colab.research.google.com/drive/1JlHKfdff\_yjCO8yvxiKV9xoRAiEPgarM\#scrollTo=jfYaOtaAsfxz\&line=3\&uniqifier=1}{Run in Google Colab \textgreater{}\textgreater{}}

\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{loanpy}\PYG{n+nn}{.}\PYG{n+nn}{scminer} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n}{get\PYGZus{}heur}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{get\PYGZus{}heur}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{eng}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}

\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{loanpy.scminer.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{uralign}}}{\sphinxparam{\DUrole{n,n}{left}\DUrole{p,p}{:}\DUrole{w,w}{  }\DUrole{n,n}{str}}, \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n,n}{right}\DUrole{p,p}{:}\DUrole{w,w}{  }\DUrole{n,n}{str}}}{{ $\rightarrow$ str}}
\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Aligns the left and right input strings based on a custom alignment
for Hungarian\sphinxhyphen{}preHungarian.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The function splits the input strings by space, aligns them one by one
and squeezes the remainder of the longer string into one single block,
which can be seen as a suffix.

\sphinxAtStartPar
It then returns the aligned strings, joined by a newline character.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Parameters}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{left}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}) \textendash{} The left input string with space\sphinxhyphen{}separated IPA\sphinxhyphen{}sounds.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{right}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}) \textendash{} The right input string with space\sphinxhyphen{}separated IPA\sphinxhyphen{}sounds.

\end{itemize}

\sphinxlineitem{Returns}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The aligned left and right strings, separated by
a newline character.

\sphinxlineitem{Return type}
\sphinxAtStartPar
str

\end{description}\end{quote}

\section{Sound Correspondence Applier}
\label{\detokenize{documentation:module-loanpy.scapplier}}\label{\detokenize{documentation:sound-correspondence-applier}}\index{module@\spxentry{module}!loanpy.scapplier@\spxentry{loanpy.scapplier}}\index{loanpy.scapplier@\spxentry{loanpy.scapplier}!module@\spxentry{module}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This module provides tools for predicting and analyzing changes in the
horizontal or vertical transfer of words. It includes the
Adrc class, which supports the adaptation and reconstruction of words based
on sound and prosodic correspondences and inventories. The module also
contains functions for repairing phonotactics.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Horizontal transfer refers to the borrowing of words
between languages in contact, while vertical transfer refers to the
inheritance of words from a parent language to its descendants.
\index{Adrc (class in loanpy.scapplier)@\spxentry{Adrc}\spxextra{class in loanpy.scapplier}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{documentation:loanpy.scapplier.Adrc}}

Adapt or Reconstruct (ADRC) class.

\sphinxAtStartPar
This class provides functionality for automatically
adapting or reconstructing words of a language,
based on sound and prosodic correspondences and inventories.
Inputs are generated by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{loanpy.scminer}}.

\pysigstartsignatures
\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{read\_sc}}}{\sphinxparam{\DUrole{n,n}{ipa}\DUrole{p,p}{:}\DUrole{w,w}{  }\DUrole{n,n}{List\DUrole{p,p}{{[}}str\DUrole{p,p}{{]}}}}, \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n,n}{howmany}\DUrole{p,p}{:}\DUrole{w,w}{  }\DUrole{n,n}{int}\DUrole{w,w}{  }\DUrole{o,o}{=}\DUrole{w,w}{  }\DUrole{default_value}{1}}}{{ $\rightarrow$ List\DUrole{p,p}{{[}}List\DUrole{p,p}{{[}}str\DUrole{p,p}{{]}}\DUrole{p,p}{{]}}}}
\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Replaces every phoneme of a word with a list of phonemes
that it can correspond to. The next phoneme it picks is
always the one that makes the least difference in terms
of absolute frequency.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Parameters}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{ipa}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{list}}) \textendash{} a tokenized/clusterised word

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{howmany}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{int}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{, }}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{default=1}}) \textendash{} The desired number of possible combinations.
This is the false positive rate if the prediction
is wrong but the false positive rate \sphinxhyphen{}1 if the
prediction is right.

\end{itemize}

\sphinxlineitem{Returns}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The information about which sounds each input sound can
correspond to.

\sphinxlineitem{Return type}
\sphinxAtStartPar
list of lists

\end{description}\end{quote}

\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{loanpy.scapplier.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{dijkstra}}}{\sphinxparam{\DUrole{n,n}{graph}\DUrole{p,p}{:}\DUrole{w,w}{  }\DUrole{n,n}{Dict\DUrole{p,p}{{[}}Tuple\DUrole{p,p}{{[}}int\DUrole{p,p}{,}\DUrole{w,w}{  }int\DUrole{p,p}{{]}}\DUrole{p,p}{,}\DUrole{w,w}{  }Dict\DUrole{p,p}{{[}}Tuple\DUrole{p,p}{{[}}int\DUrole{p,p}{,}\DUrole{w,w}{  }int\DUrole{p,p}{{]}}\DUrole{p,p}{,}\DUrole{w,w}{  }int\DUrole{p,p}{{]}}\DUrole{p,p}{{]}}}}, \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n,n}{start}\DUrole{p,p}{:}\DUrole{w,w}{  }\DUrole{n,n}{Tuple\DUrole{p,p}{{[}}int\DUrole{p,p}{,}\DUrole{w,w}{  }int\DUrole{p,p}{{]}}}}, \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n,n}{end}\DUrole{p,p}{:}\DUrole{w,w}{  }\DUrole{n,n}{Tuple\DUrole{p,p}{{[}}int\DUrole{p,p}{,}\DUrole{w,w}{  }int\DUrole{p,p}{{]}}}}}{{ $\rightarrow$ List\DUrole{p,p}{{[}}Tuple\DUrole{p,p}{{[}}int\DUrole{p,p}{,}\DUrole{w,w}{  }int\DUrole{p,p}{{]}}\DUrole{p,p}{{]}}\DUrole{w,w}{  }\DUrole{p,p}{|}\DUrole{w,w}{  }None}}
\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Find the shortest path between two nodes in a weighted graph
using Dijkstra’s algorithm.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Dijkstra’s algorithm is an algorithm for finding the shortest path
between two nodes in a weighted graph. It
maintains a priority queue of nodes to be expanded and their tentative
distances from the start node. The
algorithm iteratively extracts the node with the minimum tentative
distance from the priority queue and updates
the tentative distances of its neighbors if a shorter path is found.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Parameters}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{graph}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{dict}}) \textendash{} A dictionary representing the weighted graph, where each
key is a node and each value is a
dictionary representing its neighbors and edge weights.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{start}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{A tuple}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{ of }}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{two integers representing the node\textquotesingle{}s position on
the x and y axis.}}) \textendash{} The starting node.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{end}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{A tuple}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{ of }}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{two integers representing the node\textquotesingle{}s position on
the x and y axis.}}) \textendash{} The ending node.

\end{itemize}

\sphinxlineitem{Returns}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The shortest path between the start and end nodes,
represented as a list of nodes in the order they are
visited, or None if no path exists.

\sphinxlineitem{Return type}
\sphinxAtStartPar
list or None

\sphinxlineitem{Raises}
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{KeyError}} \textendash{} If the start or end node is not in the graph.

\end{description}\end{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxhref{https://colab.research.google.com/drive/1JlHKfdff\_yjCO8yvxiKV9xoRAiEPgarM\#scrollTo=WRYiNDPmHr5V\&line=5\&uniqifier=1}{Run in Google Colab \textgreater{}\textgreater{}}

\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{loanpy.scapplier.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{edit\_distance\_with2ops}}}{\sphinxparam{\DUrole{n,n}{string1}\DUrole{p,p}{:}\DUrole{w,w}{  }\DUrole{n,n}{str}}, \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n,n}{string2}\DUrole{p,p}{:}\DUrole{w,w}{  }\DUrole{n,n}{str}}, \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n,n}{w\_del}\DUrole{p,p}{:}\DUrole{w,w}{  }\DUrole{n,n}{int\DUrole{w,w}{  }\DUrole{p,p}{|}\DUrole{w,w}{  }float}\DUrole{w,w}{  }\DUrole{o,o}{=}\DUrole{w,w}{  }\DUrole{default_value}{100}}, \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n,n}{w\_ins}\DUrole{p,p}{:}\DUrole{w,w}{  }\DUrole{n,n}{int\DUrole{w,w}{  }\DUrole{p,p}{|}\DUrole{w,w}{  }float}\DUrole{w,w}{  }\DUrole{o,o}{=}\DUrole{w,w}{  }\DUrole{default_value}{49}}}{{ $\rightarrow$ int\DUrole{w,w}{  }\DUrole{p,p}{|}\DUrole{w,w}{  }float}}
\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Called by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{loanpy.scapplier.Adrc.get\_closest\_phonotactics}}.
Takes two strings and calculates their similarity by
only allowing two operations: insertion and deletion.
An algorithmic implementation of the “Threshold Principle”
\sphinxhref{http://www.jstor.com/stable/4176422}{(Paradis and LaCharité 1997: 385)}
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Parameters}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{string1}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}) \textendash{} The first of two strings to be compared to each other

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{string2}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}) \textendash{} The second of two strings to be compared to each other

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{w\_del}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{int}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{ or }}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{float}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{, }}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{default=100}}) \textendash{} weight (cost) for deleting a phoneme. Default should
always stay 100, since only relative costs between inserting
and deleting count.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{w\_ins}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{int}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{ or }}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{float}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{, }}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{default=49.}}) \textendash{} weight (cost) for inserting a phoneme. Default 49
is in accordance with the “Threshold Principle”:
2 insertions (2*49=98) are cheaper than a deletion (100).

\end{itemize}

\sphinxlineitem{Returns}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The distance between two input strings

\sphinxlineitem{Return type}
\sphinxAtStartPar
int or float

\end{description}\end{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxhref{https://colab.research.google.com/drive/1JlHKfdff\_yjCO8yvxiKV9xoRAiEPgarM\#scrollTo=vTJ6TnehBOGv\&line=2\&uniqifier=1}{Run in Google Colab \textgreater{}\textgreater{}}

Called by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{loanpy.scapplier.Adrc.repair\_phonotactics}}. Similar to
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{loanpy.scapplier.edit\_distance\_with2ops}} but without
weights (i.e. deletion and insertion both always cost one) and the matrix
is returned. Draws a matrix of minimum edit distances between every
substring of two input strings.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Parameters}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{target}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{iterable}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{, }}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{e.g. str}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{ or }}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{list}}) \textendash{} The target word

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{source}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{iterable}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{, }}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{e.g. str}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{ or }}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{list}}) \textendash{} The source word

\end{itemize}

\sphinxlineitem{Returns}
\sphinxAtStartPar
A matrix where every cell tells the cost of turning one
substring into the other (only delete and insert with cost 1 for
each)

\sphinxlineitem{Return type}
\sphinxAtStartPar
list of lists

\end{description}\end{quote}

\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{loanpy}\PYG{n+nn}{.}\PYG{n+nn}{scapplier} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n}{get\PYGZus{}mtx}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{get\PYGZus{}mtx}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{Bécs}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{Pécs}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{g+go}{ [1, 2, 3, 4, 5],}

\PYG{g+go}{ [3, 4, 3, 2, 3],}

\PYG{g+go}{\PYGZsh{} What happens under the hood:}
\PYG{g+go}{\PYGZsh{} deletion costs 1, insertion costs 1, so the distances are:}
\PYG{g+go}{\PYGZsh{} B C D E  \PYGZsh{} hashtag stands for empty string}
\PYG{g+go}{\PYGZsh{} 0 1 2 3 4  \PYGZsh{} distance B\PYGZhy{}\PYGZsh{}=1, BC\PYGZhy{}\PYGZsh{}=2, BCD\PYGZhy{}\PYGZsh{}=3, BCDE\PYGZhy{}\PYGZsh{}=4}

\PYG{g+go}{\PYGZsh{} E 2 3 4 3 2  \PYGZsh{} distance DE\PYGZhy{}\PYGZsh{}=2, DE\PYGZhy{}B=3, DE\PYGZhy{}BC=4, DE\PYGZhy{}BCD=3, DE\PYGZhy{}BCDE=2}
\PYG{g+go}{\PYGZsh{} the min. edit distance from BCDE\PYGZhy{}DE=2: delete B, delete C}

Moves a sound correspondence from the input list to the output

\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{loanpy.scapplier.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{mtx2graph}}}{\sphinxparam{\DUrole{n,n}{matrix}\DUrole{p,p}{:}\DUrole{w,w}{  }\DUrole{n,n}{List\DUrole{p,p}{{[}}List\DUrole{p,p}{{[}}int\DUrole{p,p}{{]}}\DUrole{p,p}{{]}}}}, \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n,n}{w\_del}\DUrole{p,p}{:}\DUrole{w,w}{  }\DUrole{n,n}{int}\DUrole{w,w}{  }\DUrole{o,o}{=}\DUrole{w,w}{  }\DUrole{default_value}{100}}, \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n,n}{w\_ins}\DUrole{p,p}{:}\DUrole{w,w}{  }\DUrole{n,n}{int}\DUrole{w,w}{  }\DUrole{o,o}{=}\DUrole{w,w}{  }\DUrole{default_value}{49}}}{{ $\rightarrow$ Dict\DUrole{p,p}{{[}}Tuple\DUrole{p,p}{{[}}int\DUrole{p,p}{,}\DUrole{w,w}{  }int\DUrole{p,p}{{]}}\DUrole{p,p}{,}\DUrole{w,w}{  }Dict\DUrole{p,p}{{[}}Tuple\DUrole{p,p}{{[}}int\DUrole{p,p}{,}\DUrole{w,w}{  }int\DUrole{p,p}{{]}}\DUrole{p,p}{,}\DUrole{w,w}{  }int\DUrole{p,p}{{]}}\DUrole{p,p}{{]}}}}
\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Converts a distance\sphinxhyphen{}matrix to a weighted directed graph
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Parameters}
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{matrix}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{A list}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{ of }}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{list}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{ of }}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{integers}}) \textendash{} The distance matrix, generated by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{loanpy.apply.get\_mtx}}.

\sphinxlineitem{W\_del}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Weight of deletions. According to the Threshold Principle of the
Theory of Constraints and Repair Strategies (TCRS,
\sphinxhref{http://www.jstor.com/stable/4176422}{Paradis and LaCharité 1997: 385}),
two insertions are cheaper than one deletion. Therefore,
the weight of deletions, i.e. moving to the right through the
matrix, is set to 49 by default.

\sphinxlineitem{W\_ins}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Weight of insertions, i.e. moving downwards through the matrix.
Set to 100 by default, so that two insertions
(2*49=98) are just cheaper than one deletion.

\sphinxlineitem{Returns}
\sphinxAtStartPar
A directed graph with weighted edges

\sphinxlineitem{Return type}
\sphinxAtStartPar
dictionary with tuples as keys and dictionaries as values.
The value\sphinxhyphen{}dictionaries contain tuples as keys and weights
(integers) as values.
All tuples contain two integers that represent the position
of a node in the matrix/graph, e.g. (0, 0).

\end{description}\end{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxhref{https://colab.research.google.com/drive/1JlHKfdff\_yjCO8yvxiKV9xoRAiEPgarM\#scrollTo=HbEz8rWFEzGi\&line=3\&uniqifier=1}{Run in Google Colab \textgreater{}\textgreater{}}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]

\index{tuples2editops() (in module loanpy.scapplier)@\spxentry{tuples2editops()}\spxextra{in module loanpy.scapplier}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{documentation:loanpy.scapplier.tuples2editops}}
\pysigstartsignatures
\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{loanpy.scapplier.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{tuples2editops}}}{\sphinxparam{\DUrole{n,n}{op\_list}\DUrole{p,p}{:}\DUrole{w,w}{  }\DUrole{n,n}{List\DUrole{p,p}{{[}}Tuple\DUrole{p,p}{{[}}int\DUrole{p,p}{,}\DUrole{w,w}{  }int\DUrole{p,p}{{]}}\DUrole{p,p}{{]}}}}, \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n,n}{s1}\DUrole{p,p}{:}\DUrole{w,w}{  }\DUrole{n,n}{str}}, \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n,n}{s2}\DUrole{p,p}{:}\DUrole{w,w}{  }\DUrole{n,n}{str}}}{{ $\rightarrow$ List\DUrole{p,p}{{[}}str\DUrole{p,p}{{]}}}}
\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Called by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{loanpy.scapplier.editops}}.
The path through the graph by which \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{string1}} is converted to
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{string2}} is given in form of tuples that contain the x and y
coordinates of every step through the matrix shaped graph.
This function converts those numerical instructions to human readable
ones. The x values stand for movement from left to right, y values for
movement downwards.
Movement downwards means deletion, movement to the right means insertion.
Diagonal movement means the value is kept.
Moving to the right and downards or downwards and to the right after each
other means substitution.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Parameters}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{op\_list}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{list}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{ of }}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{tuples}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{ of }}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{2 int}}) \textendash{} The numeric list of edit operations

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{s1}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}) \textendash{} The first of two strings to be compared to each other

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{s2}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}) \textendash{} The second of two strings to be compared to each other

\end{itemize}

\sphinxlineitem{Returns}
\sphinxAtStartPar
list of human readable edit operations

\sphinxlineitem{Return type}
\sphinxAtStartPar
list of strings

\end{description}\end{quote}

\section{Evaluate Sound Correspondence Applier}
\label{\detokenize{documentation:module-loanpy.eval_sca}}\label{\detokenize{documentation:evaluate-sound-correspondence-applier}}\index{module@\spxentry{module}!loanpy.eval\_sca@\spxentry{loanpy.eval\_sca}}\index{loanpy.eval\_sca@\spxentry{loanpy.eval\_sca}!module@\spxentry{module}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This module focuses on evaluating the quality of adapted and reconstructed
words. It processes the input data,
which consists of tokenised IPA source and target strings, as well as
prosodic strings, and extracts and applies correspondences to predict the best
possible adaptations or reconstructions. The module then
calculates the accuracy of the predictions by counting the relative number of
false positives (how many guesses) vs true positives.
Overall, this module aims to facilitate a deeper understanding of
loanword adaptation and historical sound change processes
by quantifying the success rate of predictive models.
\index{eval\_all() (in module loanpy.eval\_sca)@\spxentry{eval\_all()}\spxextra{in module loanpy.eval\_sca}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{documentation:loanpy.eval_sca.eval_all}}
\pysigstartsignatures
\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{loanpy.eval\_sca.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{eval\_all}}}{\sphinxparam{\DUrole{n,n}{intable}\DUrole{p,p}{:}\DUrole{w,w}{  }\DUrole{n,n}{List\DUrole{p,p}{{[}}List\DUrole{p,p}{{[}}str\DUrole{p,p}{{]}}\DUrole{p,p}{{]}}}}, \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n,n}{heur}\DUrole{p,p}{:}\DUrole{w,w}{  }\DUrole{n,n}{Dict\DUrole{p,p}{{[}}str\DUrole{p,p}{,}\DUrole{w,w}{  }List\DUrole{p,p}{{[}}str\DUrole{p,p}{{]}}\DUrole{p,p}{{]}}}}, \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n,n}{adapt}\DUrole{p,p}{:}\DUrole{w,w}{  }\DUrole{n,n}{bool}}, \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n,n}{guess\_list}\DUrole{p,p}{:}\DUrole{w,w}{  }\DUrole{n,n}{List\DUrole{p,p}{{[}}int\DUrole{p,p}{{]}}}}, \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n,n}{pros}\DUrole{p,p}{:}\DUrole{w,w}{  }\DUrole{n,n}{bool}\DUrole{w,w}{  }\DUrole{o,o}{=}\DUrole{w,w}{  }\DUrole{default_value}{False}}}{{ $\rightarrow$ List\DUrole{p,p}{{[}}Tuple\DUrole{p,p}{{[}}int\DUrole{p,p}{,}\DUrole{w,w}{  }int\DUrole{p,p}{{]}}\DUrole{p,p}{{]}}}}
\pysigstopsignatures\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Input a loanpy\sphinxhyphen{}compatible table containing etymological data.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Start a nested for\sphinxhyphen{}loop for

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The first loop goes through the number of guesses (\textasciitilde{} false positives)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The second loop performs \sphinxhref{https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cross-validation\_(statistics)\#Leave-one-out\_cross-validation}{leave\sphinxhyphen{}one\sphinxhyphen{}out cross validation}
with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{loanpy.eval\_sca.eval\_one}}.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The output is a list of tuples containing the relative number of
true positives vs. relative number of false positives

\end{enumerate}
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Parameters}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{intable}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{list}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{ of }}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{lists}}) \textendash{} The input tsv\sphinxhyphen{}table. Space\sphinxhyphen{}separated tokenised IPA source
and target strings must be in column “ALIGNMENT”, prosodic
strings in column “PROSODY”.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar

\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{loanpy.eval\_sca.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{eval\_one}}}{\sphinxparam{\DUrole{n,n}{intable}\DUrole{p,p}{:}\DUrole{w,w}{  }\DUrole{n,n}{List\DUrole{p,p}{{[}}List\DUrole{p,p}{{[}}str\DUrole{p,p}{{]}}\DUrole{p,p}{{]}}}}, \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n,n}{heur}\DUrole{p,p}{:}\DUrole{w,w}{  }\DUrole{n,n}{Dict\DUrole{p,p}{{[}}str\DUrole{p,p}{,}\DUrole{w,w}{  }List\DUrole{p,p}{{[}}str\DUrole{p,p}{{]}}\DUrole{p,p}{{]}}}}, \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n,n}{adapt}\DUrole{p,p}{:}\DUrole{w,w}{  }\DUrole{n,n}{bool}}, \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n,n}{howmany}\DUrole{p,p}{:}\DUrole{w,w}{  }\DUrole{n,n}{int}}, \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n,n}{pros}\DUrole{p,p}{:}\DUrole{w,w}{  }\DUrole{n,n}{bool}\DUrole{w,w}{  }\DUrole{o,o}{=}\DUrole{w,w}{  }\DUrole{default_value}{False}}}{{ $\rightarrow$ float}}
\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Called by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{loanpy.eval.eval\_all}}.
Loops through the loanpy\sphinxhyphen{}compatible etymological input\sphinxhyphen{}table and
performs \sphinxhref{https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cross-validation\_(statistics)\#Leave-one-out\_cross-validation}{leave\sphinxhyphen{}one\sphinxhyphen{}out cross validation}.
The result is how many words were correctly predicted, relative to the
total number of predictions made.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Parameters}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{intable}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{list}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{ of }}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{lists}}) \textendash{} The input tsv\sphinxhyphen{}table. Space\sphinxhyphen{}separated tokenised IPA source
and target strings must be in column “ALIGNMENT”, prosodic
strings in column “PROSODY”.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{heur}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{ or }}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{pathlike object}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{, }}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{optional}}) \textendash{} The path to the heuristic sound correspondences file,
e.g. “heur.json”, which was created with
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{loanpy.scminer.get\_heur}}.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{adapt}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{bool}}) \textendash{} Set to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{True}} to make predictions with
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{loanpy.scapplier.Adrc.adapt}}, set to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{False}} to
make predictions with
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{loanpy.scapplier.Adrc.reconstruct}}.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{howmany}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{list}}) \textendash{} Howmany guesses should be made. Treated as false positives.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{pros}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{bool}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{, }}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{default=False}}) \textendash{} Wheter phonotactic repairs should be applied

\end{itemize}

\sphinxlineitem{Returns}
\sphinxAtStartPar
A tuple with the ratio of successful predictions
(rounded to 2 decimal places).

\sphinxlineitem{Return type}
\sphinxAtStartPar
float

\end{description}\end{quote}

\section{Loan Finder}
\label{\detokenize{documentation:module-loanpy.loanfinder}}\label{\detokenize{documentation:loan-finder}}\index{module@\spxentry{module}!loanpy.loanfinder@\spxentry{loanpy.loanfinder}}\index{loanpy.loanfinder@\spxentry{loanpy.loanfinder}!module@\spxentry{module}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This module is designed to identify potential loanwords between a hypothesised
donor and recipient language. It processes two input dataframes, one
representing the donor language with predicted adapted forms and the other
the recipient language with predicted reconstructions. The module first finds
phonetic matches between the two languages and then calculates their semantic
similarity. The output is a list of candidate loanwords, which can be further
analysed manually.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The two functions in this module are responsible for finding phonetic
matches between the given donor and recipient language data and calculating
their semantic similarity. These functions process the input dataframes and
compare the phonetic patterns, as well as calculate the semantic similarity
based on a user\sphinxhyphen{}provided function. The module returns a list of candidate
loanwords that show phonetic and semantic similarities. The output can
then be used to propose lexical borrowings, adaptation patterns,
and historical reconstructions for words of the proposed donor and recipient
language.
\index{phonetic\_matches() (in module loanpy.loanfinder)@\spxentry{phonetic\_matches()}\spxextra{in module loanpy.loanfinder}}

Calculate the semantic similarity between pairs of rows in the input
data frame using the provided semantic\sphinxhyphen{}similarity scoring function, add
the information about the semantic similarity to each row. Write the file
to the provided output\sphinxhyphen{}path.

row of data. The first sublist should contain the header
row, and each subsequent sublist should contain the data
for one row. The meanings have to be in columns 4 and 5
(index 3 and 4).

\section{Utility Functions}
\label{\detokenize{documentation:module-loanpy.utils}}\label{\detokenize{documentation:utility-functions}}\index{module@\spxentry{module}!loanpy.utils@\spxentry{loanpy.utils}}\index{loanpy.utils@\spxentry{loanpy.utils}!module@\spxentry{module}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Module focusing on functions to support generating and preprocessing
loanpy\sphinxhyphen{}compatible input data.

\sphinxAtStartPar
This module contains functions for
optimal year cutoffs, manipulating IPA data, and
processing cognate sets. It provides helper functions for reading and
processing linguistic datasets and performing various operations such as
filtering and validation.

Replace gaps in the first input string based on the second input string.

\sphinxAtStartPar
This function takes two aligned strings, replaces “\sphinxhyphen{}” in the first string
with either “C” (consonant) or “V” (vowel) depending on the corresponding
character in the second string, and returns the new strings as a list.

\item {}

\end{itemize}

second string.

\index{find\_optimal\_year\_cutoff() (in module loanpy.utils)@\spxentry{find\_optimal\_year\_cutoff()}\spxextra{in module loanpy.utils}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{documentation:loanpy.utils.find_optimal_year_cutoff}}
\pysigstartsignatures
\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{loanpy.utils.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{find\_optimal\_year\_cutoff}}}{\sphinxparam{\DUrole{n,n}{tsv}\DUrole{p,p}{:}\DUrole{w,w}{  }\DUrole{n,n}{List\DUrole{p,p}{{[}}List\DUrole{p,p}{{[}}str\DUrole{p,p}{{]}}\DUrole{p,p}{{]}}}}, \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n,n}{origins}\DUrole{p,p}{:}\DUrole{w,w}{  }\DUrole{n,n}{Iterable}}}{{ $\rightarrow$ int}}
\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Determine the optimal year cutoff for a given dataset and origins.

\sphinxAtStartPar
This function reads TSV content from a given dataset and origins,
calculates the accumulated count of words with the specified origin until
each given year, and finds the optimal year cutoff using the euclidean
distance to the upper left corner in a coordinate system where the
relative increase of years is on the x\sphinxhyphen{}axis and the relative increase
in the cumulative number of words is on the y\sphinxhyphen{}axis.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Parameters}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{tsv}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{list}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{ of }}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{list}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{ of }}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{strings}}) \textendash{} A table where the first row is the header

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{origins}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{a set}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{ of }}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{strings}}) \textendash{} A set of origins to be considered for counting words.

\end{itemize}

\sphinxlineitem{Returns}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The optimal year cutoff for the dataset and origins.

\sphinxlineitem{Return type}
\sphinxAtStartPar
int

\end{description}\end{quote}

language.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The data is expected to have language IDs in the third column (index 2).
The sequence should be: source\_lang, target\_lang, source\_lang,
target\_lang, …

\pysigstartsignatures
\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{loanpy.utils.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{modify\_ipa\_all}}}{\sphinxparam{\DUrole{n,n}{input\_file}\DUrole{p,p}{:}\DUrole{w,w}{  }\DUrole{n,n}{str\DUrole{w,w}{  }\DUrole{p,p}{|}\DUrole{w,w}{  }Path}}, \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n,n}{output\_file}\DUrole{p,p}{:}\DUrole{w,w}{  }\DUrole{n,n}{str\DUrole{w,w}{  }\DUrole{p,p}{|}\DUrole{w,w}{  }Path}}}{{ $\rightarrow$ None}}
\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Original file is \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ipa\_all.csv}} from folder \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{data}} in \sphinxhref{https://pypi.org/project/panphon/0.20.0/}{panphon 0.20.0}
and was copied with the permission of its author.
The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ipa\_all.csv}} table of loanpy was created with this function.
Following modifications are undertaken:
\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
All \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{+}} signs are replaced by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{1}}, all \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}}} signs by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\sphinxhyphen{}1}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Two phonemes are appended to the column \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ipa}},
namely “C”, and “V”, meaning “any consonant”, and “any vowel”.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Any phoneme containing “j”, “w”, or “\textipa{P}” is redefined as a consonant.

\end{enumerate}
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Parameters}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{input\_file}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{A string}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{ or }}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{a path\sphinxhyphen{}like object}}) \textendash{} The path to the file \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ipa\_all.csv}}.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{output\_file}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{A string}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{ or }}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{a path\sphinxhyphen{}like object}}) \textendash{} The name and path of the new csv\sphinxhyphen{}file that is to be
written.

\end{itemize}

\sphinxlineitem{Returns}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Write new file

\sphinxlineitem{Return type}
\sphinxAtStartPar
None

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{prefilter() (in module loanpy.utils)@\spxentry{prefilter()}\spxextra{in module loanpy.utils}}

\begin{fulllineitems}

\pysigstartsignatures
\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{loanpy.utils.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{prefilter}}}{\sphinxparam{\DUrole{n,n}{data}\DUrole{p,p}{:}\DUrole{w,w}{  }\DUrole{n,n}{List\DUrole{p,p}{{[}}List\DUrole{p,p}{{[}}str\DUrole{p,p}{{]}}\DUrole{p,p}{{]}}}}, \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n,n}{srclg}\DUrole{p,p}{:}\DUrole{w,w}{  }\DUrole{n,n}{str}}, \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n,n}{tgtlg}\DUrole{p,p}{:}\DUrole{w,w}{  }\DUrole{n,n}{str}}}{{ $\rightarrow$ List\DUrole{p,p}{{[}}List\DUrole{p,p}{{[}}str\DUrole{p,p}{{]}}\DUrole{p,p}{{]}}}}
\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Filter dataset to keep only cognate sets where both source and target languages
occur.

\sphinxAtStartPar
This function filters the input dataset to retain only the cognate sets where
both source and target languages are present. The filtered dataset is then
sorted based on cognate set ID and language ID.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Parameters}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{data}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{list}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{ of }}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{list}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{ of }}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{strings}}) \textendash{} A list of lists containing language data. Columns
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Language\_ID}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Cognacy}} must be provided.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{srclg}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}) \textendash{} The source language ID to be considered.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{tgtlg}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}) \textendash{} The target language ID to be considered.

\end{itemize}

\sphinxlineitem{Returns}
\sphinxAtStartPar
A filtered and sorted list of lists containing cognate sets with both
source and target languages present.

\sphinxlineitem{Return type}
\sphinxAtStartPar
list of list of strings

\end{description}\end{quote}

\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Calculate the product of all elements in an iterable.

\sphinxAtStartPar
This function takes an iterable (e.g., list, tuple) as input and computes
the product of all its elements. This function had to be hard\sphinxhyphen{}coded
because \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{from math import prod}} caused incompatibility issues with some
python versions on certain platforms.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}

\sphinxlineitem{Returns}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The product of all elements in the input iterable.

\sphinxlineitem{Return type}
\sphinxAtStartPar
int or float

\end{description}\end{quote}
